text: you know the roads you drive on the
hospital near where you live and the
food your kids eat at school well you
might not expect this but they could all
be provided by the same big private
company there are a couple of reasons
why for a big project like building a
road or a hospital
the government doesn't necessarily have
or want to put up the cash itself it
might not want to borrow the money
either instead it would rather get a
private company to do that and then pay
them back over a number of years the
other argument goes that private
companies driven by making profit are
more efficient at doing things and
public authorities which don't have to
worry about going out of business if
they do a bad job so that's outsourcing
it probably happens in your local
hospital the cleaners wages don't come
from the NHS like the nurses wages do
instead the cleaners might get paid by a
company that's got a contract to keep
the place clean or the potholes on your
local high street the guys who come to
fill them in don't always work for the
council sometimes they'll be from a
company that's won a deal to sort it out
so private companies bid to do these
jobs and then the government gives them
the money to get on with it if it all
goes to plan the company balances its
books only spends what it has in the
bank and things get done but sometimes
it doesn't work the private security
company g4s was stripped of a contract
running a prison in Yorkshire because it
wasn't doing a good enough job and the
company got into big trouble at the
London Olympics in 2012 after it
couldn't provide all the security guards
that was supposed to for the company
more recently Karelian brilliant current
this company which was responsible for
cooking more than thirty thousand school
meals a day maintaining about half of
the UK's prisons and was given a
contract to build part of the new high
speed rail line went fast construction
giant career has gone into liquidation
Karelian had 450 public service
contracts when it collapsed it promised
to carry them out at a price it couldn't
afford and wrapped up debts of about 1.3
billion pounds in the process the whole
episode raised questions about what
would happen to the services it provided
and what it meant for its workers and
contractors that's a layer sawed off and
that was it's about home there's no work
today and it turned the principle of
outsourcing into a hot political topic
but there's one kind of outsourcing that
really gets some people worked up
it's called PFI which stands for Private
Finance Initiative this is the big stuff
it's kind of like getting a mortgage
except for a hospital or an airport or
bridges roads or a train line instead of
a house governments of all flavors
started using PFI in the 90s but it
really took off under the Labour Prime
Minister Tony Blair PFI has always been
controversial controversial Private
Finance Initiative or EFI all along a
lot of people have said that it doesn't
make sense the contracts were bad value
for money and that it would be cheaper
for the government to borrow the money
to build and manage the infrastructure
itself they're slightly suspicious about
what this may mean on top of that some
people just don't like the fact that
private companies are involved in public
services take this example in Sheffield
the council signed a two billion pound
25 year long PFI deal with a company
called ami to maintain the roads in the
city as part of their works Amy have
been chopping down trees but they say a
disease or damaging roads and pavements
but not everybody in the city is happy
about this some people are even trying
to disrupt the works people who oppose
the tree felling are angry the contract
between the City Council and the company
isn't available to view in full the
council say it's too commercially
sensitive to be released if the council
were cutting the trees down themselves
people could petition their counselors
or try to elect a new more Pro tree
council that had stopped it but with an
outsourcing company bound into a long
term contract there's not a lot they can
do
and with the lifespan of some outsource
contracts being measured in decades it's
something we'll be hearing about for a
long time
